items.title: Hey there JSTOR! Thank you for being one of my favorite reading sites. I’ve been making use of your 100 papers a month plan for people not otherwise affiliated for over a decade now, since I was around 15. I’m not a professional or anything —barely graduated highschool as it is, and late, at that—and JSTOR is by far the most comprehensive site for scientific literature for us regular nerds. Thank you for all your hard work!
items.summary: This is so kind, thank you! We're glad you've been able to use some of the scholarship outside the classroom.

items.title: Hi! I’ve been thinking A LOT about wanting to read articles, essays, and more BUT I am an adult with a full time job AND adhd that make reading difficult. Are there any resources or tools you have or know of that pertain to being able to listen to them? I know that text readers exist, but they have a difficult time with anything that’s not a straight up and down document. I would love to listen to papers while I work 🥲

items.title: Hello beloved JSTOR (tumblr), I am graduating college this upcoming Sunday and I wanted to say thank you for making my niche history paper topics actually researchable.  I am very much going to miss your unlimited access through my school’s library. I put JSTOR on my hear me out cake. I would do almost anything for that digital library.

items.title: Hi JSTOR mod :) Do you have anything on historical linguistics pedagogy, decolonizing historical linguistics, or pseudo historical linguistics? I found a very relevant chapter in the 2024 book Decolonizing Linguistics but otherwise I’m hitting a wall. I’m doing research in decolonial/liberatory pedagogy in historical linguistics, teaching applied historical linguistics, and knowledge of historical linguistics/language history in society.
items.summary: Hi! I found a chapter potentially of interest around themes of redoing and undoing within linguistic and gender frameworks, but I'm admittedly not an ...
